Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: P2C2--Recent Northeastern United States Temperature Records in the Context of the Late Holocene
Award.AbstractNarration:
Over the last century, the northeastern United States has experienced significant warming (~1.1Â°C), and a number of record high temperatures have been set around the region in recent years. Despite the massive impacts given the dense populations in this region, we do not fully understand the extent to which the trends reflect radiative forcing versus natural decadal-scale variability. Paleoclimate data provide opportunities to observe the climate system at decadal time scales that are not available from instrumental data alone, but there are currently no long-timescale, high-resolution proxy temperature data from this region that might help discern the relative influence of these factors in determining decadal temperature trends.

This research-- a collaborative effort between scientists from the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution and the Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory of Columbia University-- will develop annually-resolved reconstructions of late Holocene temperature from the northeastern United States using living and subfossil Atlantic White Cedar trees. This species is temperature-sensitive, long-lived, and well-preserved in wetland environments. The resulting reconstructions will be used to characterize variability in regional temperatures at time scales from interannual to millennial, to evaluate climate model simulations over the last millennium, and identify the signature of internal, remote, and global forcing on the climate of the northeastern United States.

The project provides long-term context for recent seasonal temperature extremes in the northeastern United States, and in particular along the coast and the very urbanized Boston-to-New York corridor, where high temperatures have important public health and ecosystem impacts. Funding supports student research at the doctoral and undergraduate level, as well as public outreach to regional citizen scientists and professionals focused on the environment.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project developed novel, continuous, precisely-dated, annually-resolved, multi-millennial late Holocene climate information from tree rings for the northeastern United States that were used to reconstruct past temperature and moisture variability in the region, as well as to date extreme coastal storm events, over the last 2000 years.  Long-term estimates of temperature and moisture from the region provide a better understanding of natural variability at time scales from interannual to multicentennial and facilitate improved decadal-scale prediction of future climate variability and change. Past climate data provide opportunities to observe the climate system at time scales that are not available from instrumental data alone. The results of this project provide much needed and long-term context for recent climate extremes in the northeastern United States, and in particular along the coast and the heavily urbanized Boston-to-New York corridor, where these events have important public health, infrastructure, and ecosystem impacts.

We used a novel combination of living and dead Atlantic white cedar trees preserved in coastal marsh environments to develop a 2000 year chronology of tree-ring widths.  A network of living tree-ring chronologies provides information that allows us to reconstruct both temperature and moisture variability over the last several centuries. Recent temperatures are higher than any time in the last two centuries and are the regional expression of large-scale patterns of winter-through-summer temperature variability and long-term trends over the Atlantic sector.  Cedar swamps that depend on rainfall for moisture are sensitive to precipitation amount and can be used to reconstruct coastal moisture balance over the last several centuries. These sites in particular improve large-scale gridded reconstruction of past soil moisture used to interpret the spatial and temporal fingerprint of extreme droughts and pluvials. Current temperature and precipitation trends are unlike those reconstructed for previous centuries: our reconstructions confirm the anomalous nature of current temperature and rainfall trends in the Northeast. Although a common feature in the past, periods of sustained aridity accompanied by cold temperatures across most of the Northeast have not occurred since the 1960's.  Ancient ghost forests provide evidence of the precise timing of past large storm events - likely hurricanes - that have made landfall in New England during the last several millennia. 

Data generated in this project are relevant not only to understanding past, present, and future climate variability, but also are immediately important for understanding regional coastal geology and ecosystem change, urban and coastal planning challenges, ecosystem science including conservation and restoration, and are further relevant for understanding land use history, successional patterns, and storm history and impact in coastal and inundated environments.
